curriculumAlignment.outcomeDescription: Solve linear equations using algebraic and graphical techniques, including equations with variables on both sides

keyConcepts.name: Equality and balance
keyConcepts.description: Understanding the equal sign as a relational symbol meaning 'is the same as', not 'calculate the answer'

keyConcepts.name: Inverse operations
keyConcepts.description: Using opposite operations (addition/subtraction, multiplication/division) to isolate variables

keyConcepts.name: Maintaining balance
keyConcepts.description: Performing the same operation on both sides of an equation to maintain equality

keyConcepts.name: One-step equations
keyConcepts.description: Solving equations requiring a single inverse operation (e.g., x + 5 = 12, 3x = 15)

keyConcepts.name: Two-step equations
keyConcepts.description: Solving equations requiring two operations in correct order (e.g., 2x + 3 = 11)

keyConcepts.name: Variables on both sides
keyConcepts.description: Collecting like terms when variable appears on both sides (e.g., 3x + 2 = x + 10)

keyConcepts.name: Equations with brackets
keyConcepts.description: Expanding brackets before solving using distributive law (e.g., 2(x + 3) = 14)

keyConcepts.name: Equations with fractions
keyConcepts.description: Handling fractional coefficients and terms (e.g., x/2 + 3 = 7, (2x-1)/3 = 5)

keyConcepts.name: Word problems to equations
keyConcepts.description: Translating real-world situations into linear equations and interpreting solutions

keyConcepts.name: Verifying solutions
keyConcepts.description: Checking answers by substituting back into original equation

commonMisconceptions.misconception: The equal sign means 'calculate the answer' or 'put the answer here'
commonMisconceptions.correction: The equal sign is a relational symbol meaning 'is the same as' - both sides must have the same value
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Use balance scale visualisations; emphasise 'same value on both sides'

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Operations can be applied to just one side of the equation
commonMisconceptions.correction: Whatever operation is performed on one side must be performed on the other to maintain equality
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Use physical balance scales; emphasise 'what you do to one side, do to the other'

commonMisconceptions.misconception: The negative sign only means subtraction, not a property of the number
commonMisconceptions.correction: Negative numbers are distinct values; the negative sign is part of the number itself
commonMisconceptions.exampleError: In x - (-3) = 7, student subtracts 3 instead of adding 3
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Review integer operations; use number line; separate subtraction operation from negative sign

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Ignoring brackets and order of operations
commonMisconceptions.correction: Brackets indicate multiplication applies to everything inside; must expand before solving
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Emphasise distributive law; practice expanding brackets separately first

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Adding terms incorrectly across the equals sign
commonMisconceptions.correction: Only like terms on the same side can be combined; moving terms requires inverse operations
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Clear separation of 'collecting' vs 'solving'; work on one term at a time

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Solving in wrong order for multi-step equations
commonMisconceptions.correction: Undo operations in reverse order: deal with addition/subtraction before multiplication/division
commonMisconceptions.exampleError: 2x + 6 = 14 → divide by 2 first → x + 6 = 7 → x = 1 (instead of x = 4)

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Variable represents a specific unknown rather than a placeholder for any value
commonMisconceptions.correction: In equations, x represents a specific unknown value that can be determined; in inequalities it can represent many values
commonMisconceptions.exampleError: Student thinks x must always equal the same thing in all problems
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Vary letter used; discuss how x changes meaning based on context

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Fractions in equations are handled like whole numbers
commonMisconceptions.correction: Multiply both sides by the denominator to eliminate fractions, or find common denominator
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Emphasise multiplying ENTIRE both sides; bracket all terms when multiplying

scaffoldingSequence.name: Foundation - Understanding Equality
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Relational understanding of equals sign; balance model

scaffoldingSequence.name: Building - One and Two-Step Equations
activities: One-step equations with all four operations

cognitiveLoadNotes: Introduce balance model visually before algebraic manipulation
Use worked examples with fading (Cooper & Sweller, 1987)
Break multi-step problems into explicit sub-steps
Limit new notation and vocabulary per lesson
engagementStrategies: Start with puzzle/mystery framing ('What number am I thinking of?')
Use personally relevant contexts (phone plans, gaming, part-time work)
Error analysis activities - find the mistake
motivationFactors: Connect to financial literacy and real purchasing decisions
Quick wins with one-step equations build confidence

interleaving.rationale: Rohrer & Taylor (2007) found 30-40% improvement when mixing equation types
interleaving.implementation: After phase 2, mix one-step and two-step; after phase 3, mix all types

desirableDifficulties: Vary surface features while keeping structure similar
Include 'no solution' and 'identity' equations in later phases
Reverse problems - create equation from solution

testingEffect.timing: Quiz after each phase; cumulative review every 3rd lesson
testingEffect.format: Mix recall (solve from scratch) with recognition (identify correct step)

struggling: Extended work with balance model manipulatives
More one-step equation practice before progressing
Calculator allowed for arithmetic to focus on algebraic thinking
advanced: Create own word problems for peers

formative: Exit tickets with one equation per lesson
summative: Mix of procedural and application questions
Include verification step in marking criteria
Real-world problem requiring equation setup and solution
successCriteria: Can explain why balance must be maintained
Can translate simple word problems to equations
